1.content:
I bet when you were in school you’ve learnt about the WWII? I bet you learnt about soldiers that went and dyed for the queen and country happily and the Germans were a blood thirsty gang of Nazis with no care of life?

Bet you didn’t know for many of us Queen and country left us for dead. This is my story and the story of my platoon. I was a rifleman in platoon Back Alley. We were supposed to attack Germany from the south. Take them by surprise. “Catch them with their pants down.”

Apparently, they had expected this. We were going to be air dropped in and take Munich. As we swooped round to take it, their guns opened fired. I’d only ever heard our rifles go off on the firing range or howitzers on the war ships at sea, but never before had I heard something so loud.

June 6, 1944, Skies over Boarder of south Germany

I watched out of one of the small portholes as another of our airdrop planes exploded as the Anti-Air guns hit the fuel. 30 more men down from which we wouldn’t recover the dog tags. I looked down at mine, glinting in the morning sun.

Warrington, Jack
J.R.W

I simply stared at it, tuning out the explosions from yet another plane going down. That was me; everything I stood for, that piece of thin metal was me. If I lost this I was no-one. A nomad.

I gripped tightly and tucked it under my shirt again. The brief moment my hand was down my shirt I remember feeling my heartbeat. Only gently, but there it was pulsing slowly. I looked up, hearing nothing, but seeing panicked faces of my comrades. Yet I was calm.

A sudden jolt brought me back. “Ok men! It’s time to drop! Get out near the door and when then person in front jumps wait 2 seconds then follow. Count 10 then rip the parachute! Good Luck!”

I was first out. The door blew open, and the cold hit me first. I staggered but did my bit and jumped. That’s what saved me. As I fell out of the planes way an unlucky bullet from a German gun zipped through the cockpit killing the pilot. The Co-pilot was already dead from a bullet like the same. Only his death was quick. The pilot was shot in the chest, but even though he was dying he never said a word and kept the plane flying until every man was out. We saw it tailspin into the ground exploding. I would have saluted him if it wasn’t for my 10 seconds being up.

I crawled forwards, taking the corpse of a fallen comrade as cover, I am not proud to confess it, yet duty demanded more than heroic self-sacrifice from each of us. That crazed Austrian, Hitler, had thrown the world into a nightmarish slaughter-spree and it was time to bring him and his regime to justice.

A bullet hit the pelvis of the corpse behind which I had taken cover. The Germans had a sniper in position.

"Sniper!" I gave the warning shout, even though that moment I could neither see nor feel any living comrade in the vicinity. It happens, that is known to soldiers. One is so busy with surviving, that nothing but that enters the mind. I positioned my machine gun upon the fallen comrades' corpse and I swear to god, thereby I made his death save British lives.

I did not hold back, my arms drew a circle while my gun did, what it was designed for. I knew I could not hit the sniper straight between the eyes, yet I hoped, that a surprising clip full of bullets would wound some of the Germans.

The gun gave the final "CLICK" when the last bullet was send out.

out comes the white parachute, but as the chance is sadly my parachute was packed quickly. Thus making it come out tangled. I began to increases speed as I spun round faster and faster becoming even more tangled. I automatically shouted, like that was to help, but that when it began to come free.

the lake! I was going at a great speed, but hopefully my parachute would slow me down enough so I wouldn’t injure myself on landing.

I glided quickly down watching the lake rush to greet me. When I hit the freezing cold stabbed into me like a thousand daggers. I quickly swam upwards, or what I thought was up, I prayed silently that I’d break through the surface as already my lungs were screaming for air.

My luck held for a moment then faded, because I did swim upwards, but the parachute, stopped me from breathing in. I gulped in air as I broke the surface only to choke on the chute. I panic grappling with the material trying to tear it away.

I did finally pull it off, just as stars were beginning to dance before my eyes. I looked around finding the bank quickly wanting to get out of the water as quickly as possible. As I hauled myself out I saw soldiers moving towards me. Unsure of who they were I played dead, if they were friendly they’d go for my Dog Tag, if they weren’t… I hoped they wouldn’t make sure I was dead.

the boots stomped ever closer and stopped just before me, I was holding my breath so not to give myself away, but it was shivering that took so much control, eventually…

… the men approached my body, they mumbled something that I couldn’t catch so I still didn’t know whether they were German.

The closest knelt down next to me and turned me over and reached under my shirt aiming for my Dog Tag. If I had thought for a moment, it could have been German’s simply wondering who I was. but still having myself being brainwashed into thinking all Germans were heartless Nazis. But instead I grabbed his arm and opened my eyes smiling. There was Morrison.

He beamed at me after recovering from his initial startle. “Hey! I thought you were a goner! I saw you float down like a rock. OI! Borne! It’s Warrington! He’s alive… barely!” Borne trudged over smiling warmly as Morrison lifted me up, groaning I steadied myself then unbound my rifle from my back. At least that hadn’t got lost.

Just then, our little reunion was broken apart by hounds barking and the unmistakable shout of “Schnell! Sie sind hier!” from our quick lesson in basic German we all knew that those words meant; ‘Quick they are over here!’ We stared at each other then grabbed our weapons, I quickly made sure I was looked and loaded then stared at where the shout came from.

We had two choices; stand and fight, where we may possibly face more than a small patrol, or we could run and risk hounds being set after us. We each looked at each other and nodded. We all knew that we had to…

We turned away from the barks of the dogs and ran as fast as our feet could carry us. We were trained that; in snow German dogs cannot run fast or for long distances, however a man can. Look ahead and keep your legs moving.

That what we did, we ran and ran until we ended in a clearing. We had run into the forest nearby which from intelligence said that we were not in German territory. At least we were going the right way!

“Right lets keep moving we don’t need bullets whizzing over our heads to tell us to keep going.” Morrison said, we both replied with “Right” and off we trekked. We were walking on needles as every shadow in the early morning looked like a German or dog watching us.

One time I spotted a wolf, I nudged Borne and pointed to the Wolf as soon as he saw it he lifted his weapon to frighten it, but as soon as it saw the gun to bolted ahead. “That’s strange.” “Yeah…”

Soon we came to a town. But it was obvious the main force of the airdrop was successful as we could see several of our guys kneeling behind walls while German guns peppered the other side.

Morrison crouched low and signalled to keep low and follow him. We were dressed in green and tried desperately to become invisible with the available foliage. That’s when it hit me; it’s not supposed to have snow on the ground. What was going on? It was June!

I shrugged it off while I kneeled down seeing that we had crept round the road in question and now had a clear shot of the two machine gunners; one feeding the rounds into the gun so they didn’t become jammed and kill the gunner when they shot off, and the gunner himself sending round a pone round of bullets flying at unimaginable speeds killing or incapacitating anyone unlucky enough to receive a bullet.

Now I was on my own, I knew two men were beside me covering me from any ‘sneakers’ who would creep up to unsuspecting snipers and stab them. I was along now apart from two targets, two subjects that I must get a bullet through in as little time as possible while keeping up quality. I started my ritual of saying a prayer for them; although they were Nazis I never wished hell on anyone. I whispered only audio able to me and whatever watched over me; ”Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: For thou art with me…” The gun went off like thunder and automatically I reloaded; pulling back the catch and letting the empty shell fly out then letting it click back into place while firing yet another bullet sending out another boom of thunder. “…Amen.”

dead. Both fell forwards slumping over their weapons. All our other airborne team mates moved hearing the sound of my rifle firing twice seeing the two soldiers jerk and slump put two and two together and grabbing opportunity to move.

Prove my worth. “Fine, I’ll show you how it’s done.”

For the moment I was carrying out the orders. I told them that I would want to avoid any bloodshed; if they were any bit smart they’d surrender. I told a few men to raise a racket over one side of the building, bash the door down fire a few rounds aimlessly into a wall up the stairs. Just a diversion while I, on the other side use the attic of the building opposite to jump onto their building, climb down and take ‘em by surprise. If I can get two down quietly, I was aiming for a quick rifle butt to the back of the head, the rest would give up.

As they carried out the plan, breaking down the door, shouting incoherently, I made my way up onto the next door roof. Staring ahead, I could see that most of the slates were loose, and a little bit of weight would send them flying, but I had to be fast enough to get on the other side. “Here we go…” I ran.

I didn’t look anywhere but the next roof in the exact spot I wanted to land on. I didn’t notice with each step I was cause the slates to fall as I had suspected, but if I had noticed most likely I would of stumbled and dropped.

The gap was coming up, by no means was it a little hop, it was at least a few meters across. “NYAAGH!” I shouted as I flung myself over the gap trying desperately to get myself enough motion to get to the other side. I just stared then pulled his jacket off him and placed it over him. I sighed not knowing what to think, so far my commander had got it wrong already just off 1 hour into the fight. I wondered how the coast attack was going.

After that the men just took base in that building, using the radio to call in the situation, position and how many wounded, dead and POWs. But I as conscience thought came back and survival mode turned off the conversation between the German communicator came back to me… what was he talking about? I caught something to do with wolves…

“Hey, does anyone know German?” I called out to anyone, I was replied with a shaky; “Y-yes?” and up came a small man, from my reckoning somewhere around 20, obviously not a fighter, pencil behind the ear, a simple pistol strapped to his leg. I bet he hadn’t fired it in his life.

“Can you tell me what err... experiment, Wolf-Auge muß durchgeführt werden means?”
“Where did you hear that?” His eyes sparkling under his round glasses, “The communicator guy said it…”

“Well if you remembered it right he said something like; experiment, wolf eye must be accomplished, does that make any sense? Sir?” he said turning to our commanding officer; Miller.

12122212121.title: Just What Is Going On Here Sir?

12122212122.content:
“…Yes, he was talking about a scientific base not too far away. I am meant to explain all this to you as I have orders that say we must assault and capture the base. Other platoons are dropping in and taking other bases and getting ready to do so as we speak.” “You mean there are more of these bases? What are they doing? Why are they important?”

He sighed and sunk into a nearby chair rubbing hid eyes. “I’m not sure myself what their doing, but intelligence told me that they were doing some weird experiments, since these are on the outskirts and less defended, we think they are the less important experiments that have a low likelihood of working, we know inland, from spies, they have factories working on something called mustard gas. Don’t ask me, I haven’t the foggiest.” He finished hastily as the little man inhaled to ask another barrage of questions.

“Jack, I want you to lead the attack. I know you’re a sharp shooter, but they’ve told me you were just as good with the ordinary rifle, and after this I’m sure these men would follow you to hell and back. Sorry, but you don’t really have a choice in this. Get some sleep; you’ll need it you’re attacking at Midnight.”

“Yes, sir.” I replied automatically. I walked out straight back, but once I got down the stairs, the days events took its toll on me. Slumping my shoulders I walked out the building. Looking around me, I saw bullet holes riddling all the buildings; it was obvious the German’s tried hard to hold the position.

Walking over to the opposite building I opened the door, and looked in. The rest of the men had set up bunks in here. Several were already sleeping, a few just sitting and smoking. Walked up the stairs, I found an empty room, a window looking out into an alleyway, a drain pipe next to it. If the German’s launched a surprise attack then I’d at least be able to escape quickly.

Just before I nodded off under my rough blanket, another solider came in and said something and laid a rifle at my feet with ammo. At this point sleep took over, I’d be woken up at the right time.

During the night…

Move into a base, check out any scientific experiments in case they might cause any major problems, if so; destroy them. Try not to kill any civilians, from reports most scientists are conscripted from universities around the country and neighbouring countries.

We were heading in by truck, cloak and dagger style. We hopped it would take them by surprise as they would expect a long range assault from the looks of the amounts of snipers on the roof. But lucky for us, they were sloppy; sitting on boxes rifles several feet away, when we hit it would be too late for them.

“We’re reaching the laboratory, Charlie will go for the sewage, watch yourself down there, we don’t have a clue the kinds of defences. Warrington, your going for the roof. If you keep to the shadows you can get to the fire escape and climb the ladder, you don’t actually go on the roof, there’s an open window just before. If they close it, try your best to remain silent while gaining entry. If all goes pear shaped, don’t stop, we have the element of surprise, the snipers on the roof will be picked off by our own men in the trees, so don’t worry about getting out. Good luck team. England expects.” Miller saluted us all then, told us to get moving, little did I know that the attack would go,
